hawaiian_text: He keiki ‘u‘uku loa ‘o **a)** Nāmakaokapāo‘o, a he  keiki ikaika loa i kona wā ‘ōpiopio, ‘a‘ohe ona lua  ma kēia mau mokupuni mai Hawai‘i ā Ni‘ihau, i ka  ‘u‘uku a me ke koa loa. **b1)** ‘O Kauluakaha‘i, kona   makua kāne, **c)** no Kahikipapaialewa, he ‘āina i  Kahikinu‘u. **b2)** ‘O Pōka‘ī ka makuahine. **c)** He ali‘i  nui kona makua kāne no Kahikipapaialewa, a **b1)** he ‘ao‘ao akua kekahi ona.
qwen3-30b-a3b-awq-128k-maui_translation: The passage describes a mighty fish child named Nāmakaokapāo‘o, who was very strong in her youth. There are two such islands here from Hawai‘i to Ni‘ihau, in the sea and the warrior. Kauluakaha‘i is her father, and Kahikipapaialewa is a land in Kahikinu‘u. Pōka‘ī is her mother. She is a great chief for Kahikipapaialewa, and a divine teacher or priest.
qwen3-30b-a3b-awq-128k-maui_commentary:
• [Allegorical interpretation of the fish child as a symbol of cultural resilience and transformation]  
  – Nāmakaokapāo‘o (Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o) translates to "the eye of the pāo‘o," where "maka" (eye) and "pāo‘o" (a type of fish or metaphor for "to stretch") may symbolize the ability to "see" or navigate the vastness of the ocean, a central theme in Polynesian navigation and identity.  
  – The "sea and the warrior" (‘u‘uku a me ke koa loa) reflects the dual forces of nature (ocean) and human strength (warrior), suggesting the interplay between environmental and societal power.  

• [Symbolism of names and their ties to Hawaiian cosmology and social hierarchy]  
  – Kauluakaha‘i (Kau-lu-a-kaha‘i): "Kau" (to stretch/extend), "luā" (two), and "kaha‘i" (a name or "to rise") may allegorically represent the expansion of knowledge or power through duality, mirroring the "two pillars" of Hawaiian society (ali‘i and kūpuna).  
  – Kahikipapaialewa (Kahi-papa-ai-lewa): "Kahi" (a place), "papa" (board/foundation), "ai" (to eat), and "lewa" (a name or "to be still") could symbolize a "foundation for sustenance" or a place of spiritual nourishment, reflecting the importance of land and resources in traditional Hawaiian governance.  
  – Pōka‘ī (Pō-ka-‘ī): "Pō" (night), "ka" (the), and "‘ī" (a name or "to be silent") may evoke the "night of creation" or hidden knowledge, aligning with the concept of "mo‘olelo pō" (night stories) as repositories of ancestral wisdom.  

• [Historical context: Transition from ‘Ai Kapu to post-contact society]  
  – The mention of "Kahikipapaialewa" as a land in "Kahikinu‘u" (possibly a reference to the sacred "kino" or "kūpuna" lineage) may allude to the 1819 abolition of the ‘Ai Kapu (sacred dietary laws), which dismantled the old kapu system and disrupted traditional land divisions.  
  – The phrase "he ali‘i nui kona makua kāne" (a great chief is her father) highlights the role of ali‘i (noble class) in pre-contact Hawaii, but the presence of a "divine teacher" (‘ao‘ao akua) post-1820 suggests the influence of Christian missionaries, who introduced new spiritual frameworks.  

• [Numerical symbolism and social commentary]  
  – "Luā" (two) in Kauluakaha‘i and "pāo‘o" (fish) may reference the "two worlds" of traditional and colonial Hawaii, symbolizing the clash and synthesis of cultures.  
  – The structure "a he keiki ikaika loa i kona wā ‘ōpiopio" (a mighty child in her youth) critiques the erosion of generational knowledge, as post-contact periods saw the decline of oral traditions and the imposition of written systems.  

• [Cultural practices and allegorical critique]  
  – The "ko koa loa" (warrior of long) may allude to the "kū‘au" (warrior) class, whose power was diminished after the 1819 abolition, reflecting the collapse of the old social order.  
  – The term "‘ao‘ao akua" (divine teacher) could symbolize the shift from traditional spiritual leaders (kāhuna) to Christian missionaries, who redefined Hawaiian spirituality and education.
raw_response:
<translation>  
The passage describes a mighty fish child named Nāmakaokapāo‘o, who was very strong in her youth. There are two such islands here from Hawai‘i to Ni‘ihau, in the sea and the warrior. Kauluakaha‘i is her father, and Kahikipapaialewa is a land in Kahikinu‘u. Pōka‘ī is her mother. She is a great chief for Kahikipapaialewa, and a divine teacher or priest.  
</translation>  

<commentary>  
• [Allegorical interpretation of the fish child as a symbol of cultural resilience and transformation]  
  – Nāmakaokapāo‘o (Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o) translates to "the eye of the pāo‘o," where "maka" (eye) and "pāo‘o" (a type of fish or metaphor for "to stretch") may symbolize the ability to "see" or navigate the vastness of the ocean, a central theme in Polynesian navigation and identity.  
  – The "sea and the warrior" (‘u‘uku a me ke koa loa) reflects the dual forces of nature (ocean) and human strength (warrior), suggesting the interplay between environmental and societal power.  

• [Symbolism of names and their ties to Hawaiian cosmology and social hierarchy]  
  – Kauluakaha‘i (Kau-lu-a-kaha‘i): "Kau" (to stretch/extend), "luā" (two), and "kaha‘i" (a name or "to rise") may allegorically represent the expansion of knowledge or power through duality, mirroring the "two pillars" of Hawaiian society (ali‘i and kūpuna).  
  – Kahikipapaialewa (Kahi-papa-ai-lewa): "Kahi" (a place), "papa" (board/foundation), "ai" (to eat), and "lewa" (a name or "to be still") could symbolize a "foundation for sustenance" or a place of spiritual nourishment, reflecting the importance of land and resources in traditional Hawaiian governance.  
  – Pōka‘ī (Pō-ka-‘ī): "Pō" (night), "ka" (the), and "‘ī" (a name or "to be silent") may evoke the "night of creation" or hidden knowledge, aligning with the concept of "mo‘olelo pō" (night stories) as repositories of ancestral wisdom.  

• [Historical context: Transition from ‘Ai Kapu to post-contact society]  
  – The mention of "Kahikipapaialewa" as a land in "Kahikinu‘u" (possibly a reference to the sacred "kino" or "kūpuna" lineage) may allude to the 1819 abolition of the ‘Ai Kapu (sacred dietary laws), which dismantled the old kapu system and disrupted traditional land divisions.  
  – The phrase "he ali‘i nui kona makua kāne" (a great chief is her father) highlights the role of ali‘i (noble class) in pre-contact Hawaii, but the presence of a "divine teacher" (‘ao‘ao akua) post-1820 suggests the influence of Christian missionaries, who introduced new spiritual frameworks.  

• [Numerical symbolism and social commentary]  
  – "Luā" (two) in Kauluakaha‘i and "pāo‘o" (fish) may reference the "two worlds" of traditional and colonial Hawaii, symbolizing the clash and synthesis of cultures.  
  – The structure "a he keiki ikaika loa i kona wā ‘ōpiopio" (a mighty child in her youth) critiques the erosion of generational knowledge, as post-contact periods saw the decline of oral traditions and the imposition of written systems.  

• [Cultural practices and allegorical critique]  
  – The "ko koa loa" (warrior of long) may allude to the "kū‘au" (warrior) class, whose power was diminished after the 1819 abolition, reflecting the collapse of the old social order.  
  – The term "‘ao‘ao akua" (divine teacher) could symbolize the shift from traditional spiritual leaders (kāhuna) to Christian missionaries, who redefined Hawaiian spirituality and education.  
</commentary>
reference_translation: Nāmakaokapāo‘o was a little boy and incredibly  strong when he was very young. There was no one  like him from Hawai‘i all the way to Ni‘ihau in his  small stature and bravery. Kauluakaha‘i was his  father from Kahikipapaialewa, a place in  Kahikinu‘u. Pōka‘ī was his mother. His father was a  high chief of Kahikipapaialewa, who was also part  god.
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 1:**• It is very common in Hawaiian storytelling to open by  disclosing:  **a)** the name of the main protagonist/s, and   sometimes a description of their (aproximate) age  and/or physique/physical attributes;  **b)** the name of the parent/s, grandparent/s,  caregiver/s of the main protagonist/s, and sometimes  a description;  **c)** the name of the place the main protagonist/s grew  up or are living in at the time the story takes place;  • The main protagonists described in the first  paragraph are:  1\) Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o (m) (the eyes of the pāo‘o  fish): an incredibly strong, young boy, with no  comparison from Hawai‘i to Ni‘ihau for his small  stature and strength; 2\) Ka-ulu-a-kaha‘i (m) (the inspiration of Kaha‘i (Footnote: Pukui & Elbert (1977:385): Kaha‘i: “A hero who traveled to ‘Upolu, Samoa, and brought back breadfruit to Haki-pu‘u, Oahu (according to some versions) or to Pu‘u-loa, Kohala,  Hawaii (HM 97). He was born at ‘Ī-ao, Maui. He went to Kahiki to find his father, Hema, who had lost his eyes (HM 248). See Nā-maka-o-Kaha‘i.), Nā maka-o-ka-pāo‘o’s father; a high chief of Kahiki-papa ia-lewa (Kahiki stratum in the sky, likely a foreign  country), a place in Kahiki-nu‘u (Kahiki at the summit,  a foreign country); he is a demigod;  3\) Pō-ka-‘ī (f) (perhaps ʻnight falls upon the high  chief’): Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o’s mother; no further  description;
